title: 107_hr800
content: The Act titled "Capital Gains Sunset Act" introduces a 100 percent capital gains deduction under Section 1201 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Act titled "Capital Gains Sunset Act" introduces a 100 percent capital gains deduction under Section 1201 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This deduction applies to taxpayers with a net capital gain for the taxable year, with specific rules for estates and trusts, coordination with investment interest limitations, and transitional rules for certain taxable years. The Act "Capital Gains Sunset Act" introduces a 100 percent capital gains deduction under Section 1201 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. For taxable years including January 1, 2005, special rules apply to limit the net capital gain taken into account and reduce the amount for pass-thru entities. The determination of gains and losses for pass-thru entities is made at the entity level. A pass-thru entity includes regulated investment companies, real estate investment trusts, S corporations, partnerships, estates or trusts, and common trust funds. The Act allows a deduction for long-term capital gains under Section 1201 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The deduction for long-term capital gains under Section 1201 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by technical and conforming changes, including adjustments to various code sections. The taxpayer sold the contributed property at fair market value. Section 172(d)(2) limits deductions for losses on capital assets to gains. Section 453A(c)(3) amends the deduction for long-term capital gains under Section 1201. The deduction for long-term capital gain is amended by inserting "the deduction under section 1201 shall be taken into account." Various sections of the tax code are amended to adjust deductions related to capital assets held for more than 1 year. The deduction for long-term capital gain under section 1201 shall be adjusted for estates and trusts, with certain limitations on unrelated business income. Amendments are made to various sections of the tax code to exclude the deduction under section 1201 from being taken into account. Amendments are made to various sections of the tax code, including repealing paragraph (2) of section 801(a) and amending subsection (c) of section 831 by redesignating paragraphs. Additionally, changes are made to section 852(b) regarding the deduction for dividends paid. Amendments are made to section 857(b) of the tax code, including excluding the net capital gain amount and striking certain clauses. Amendments to various sections of the tax code include changes to the treatment of net capital gains, deductions for dividends paid, and taxable income from sources outside the United States. Amendments to the tax code include changes to the treatment of net capital gains and deductions for dividends paid. Amendments to the tax code involve changes in tax rates specified by the Secretary and the removal of certain clauses related to tax calculations. Amendments to the tax code include changes in tax rates specified by the Secretary and the removal of certain clauses related to tax calculations. Additionally, the Merchant Marine Act, 1936, is amended to exempt nonqualified withdrawals from the capital gain account from tax imposition. Amendments to the tax code, including changes in tax rates and the removal of certain clauses, will apply to taxable years ending after December 31, 2004. Contributions made after January 1, 2005, will be affected by the changes. Amounts paid after the enactment of the Act will be subject to withholding amendments. The Tax Reform Act of 1986 exempts section 1122(h) from being considered when applying section 1201 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.
